text: I'm a technology forecaster which means
I spend my time exploring the
intersection between technological
advancements and
Entrepreneurship technology advances as
conversation between inventors and
Society inventors propose and Society
disposes and it's that process that has
delivered all the surprises some some
welcome some unwelcome in our lives over
the last couple of decades what I really
am is a historian of Technology who
spends most of his time looking at
technologies that don't exist yet
looking at the historic pattern of
Technology Innovation and adoption can
tell us volumes about how things will
evolve in the future and and in fact you
can pull out some very simple rules
perhaps the simplest is when it comes to
advancing Technologies never mistake a
clear view for a short distance just
because a technology looks like it's
about to arrive in the very near future
chances are there will be some surprises
and in the long run even the most
expected of Futures tends to arrive late
and in completely unexpected
ways well I
advise as a technology forecaster part
of my job is advi advising businesses on
strategies and when it works best the
businesses use the long-term perspective
on technological change to set long-term
directions and also use that perspective
as peripheral
vision as a way to identify short-term
opportunities or short-term
threats the most important thing that a
company can do in the midst of this
economic turmoil is to not lose sight of
the long-term perspective don't confuse
the short-term crisis with the long-term
trends amidst all of this short-term
change are some
fundamental structural Transformations
happening in the economy and the best
way to stay in business is to not allow
the short-term distractions to cause you
to ignore what is happening in the long
term you know there's a lot of a lot of
focus on preserving cash and hunkering
down at the moment and Sequoia Capital
famously sent out a PowerPoint in the
fall of 2008 to its companies that
basically said look preserve your bodily
fluids Cash's King don't look to us for
help if you get into trouble and and of
course that's the main theme but also I
think it's a very good idea to have a
strong contrarian instinct
it's not just conserving cash at this
moment but this may be the moment in
which it is especially valuable to
strategically spend some of the cash
you're Hoarding in order to set up for
what the next order is to come along so
saving cash is something that is
answered in the specific not in the
general but do not focus exclusively on
saving CL cash this may be the right
time to spend cash wisely
we have tended to use new technologies
in companies in two ways either to lower
costs or to create more effective ways
of approaching the market the using
technology merely to lower operational
costs amounts to standing on a whale
fishing for minnow it just allows you to
do the old thing more efficiently where
in this moment of deep trans
transformation it is much more likely
that you should be doing something
entirely new in an entirely different
way so if you focus on technology solely
as a way to squeeze expense out of your
existing business you're probably doing
it at the cost of ignoring what your
future business will be so my advice is
don't use technology primarily to lower
costs use technology to create new
effective
ways of touching the market and creating
new businesses and if you do that right
the cost savings will
come I I really think that every good
executive should have a really strong
contrarian
Instinct And when everybody else is in a
down Market is focusing on what they're
doing wrong instead focus on what you
should be doing differently it may be
that what you did in the past was
perfectly right it is possible to do all
the right things in business and still
have a business crisis because of what's
happening in the external environment
and if you start focusing on mistakes
only you're going to miss opportunities
but above all Executives in this moment
of deep uncertainty will be most
effective if they listen to the
contrarian in
them the important thing about customer
service in an age of the web and the
internet is above all be honest and make
expectations realistic don't promise
what you can't deliver don't let your
enthusiasm for your company claim that
service is better than it is take a
company like Amazon you cannot reach a
human being at Amazon well you can but
it's very very hard and yet everybody's
very happy with Amazon's customer
service because Amazon makes it really
clear if you have have a problem send us
an email they don't promise that you'll
be able to reach a human operator they
do exactly what they say and that is
talk to us via
email I think the most important thing
that a company can do not just in the
customer space but the employee space is
to be completely open and completely
honest don't pretend that you're doing
something that you cannot do there's an
old saying in Silicon Valley it's not a
bug it's a Fe
and so a lot of companies say gosh you
know we can't talk to our customers we
can't interact with them properly that's
really a problem well that may be a
feature your customers May in fact not
want to interact with you and if you're
just upfront with customers that you
can't interact with them they will
handle their own customer
service the best way to let people go is
to let them know when they're hired that
it's an uncertain Environ IR M and that
their job is always at risk and even if
you let them go it's not that you don't
love them we do this quite well here in
Silicon Valley the economic bargain when
you join a startup company is you know
it is a risky proposition and the
company may not exist and if it doesn't
there's no expectation of Lifetime
employment so I think companies over the
last 10 years have done a very bad job
of explaining to their employees what
the intrinsic risks are all I know is if
you wait until you let the employee go
to deal with the issue of how do you
communicate to the employee about being
let go it's too late to do
anything Clarity in this period of
uncertainty is absolutely essential to
employee morale and the clarity goes not
just to how long their job will last but
to the nature of a job look at the Deep
transformation in what a job is and how
it's changed over the last couple of
decades once upon a time a job was a
unitary thing it was a mixture tries
number once upon a time you were hired
with the expectation you'd work at the
same place for your entire career a
couple of decades later the expectation
changed that well I'm not going to be at
one company for my entire career but I'm
going to have one profession for my
entire career and then during the '90s
it was well not only am I not going to
work at one place for my entire career I
will probably have a series of
professions interspersed with going back
for additional education so the nature
of a job is constantly changing it's
becoming much more transient much more
volatile and then the thing you're
actually hired for is changed we call it
a job but it's actually a mixture of
Rights and obligations there is
healthare salary vacation expectations
on performance well we're breaking all
those things apart we're taking a
cafeteria approach to jobs now where
someone may be a consultant but have
more benefits than a regular employee so
the very notion of a job as a
traditional job is
disappearing and that's going to raise
the burden on companies to explain to
employees not just when they're hired
but through their entire time at the
company just what it is that they're
being compensated for and how it's
changing there is a profound change of
foot in the economy today and to make
sense of what's happening now you have
to go back a hundred years a hundred
years ago we had an emerging industrial
economy the central actor was the worker
and the symbol of that economy was the
time clock because companies then the
big industrial concerns were utterly
preoccupied with making enough stuff
cheaply enough to satisfy the demands of
an emergent working class and middle
class and we spent 50 years perfecting
the industrial
economy and after World War II when
companies returned back to making things
for consumers they discovered to their
horror they had gotten so good at making
stuff that they were now making more
stuff than people wanted and that was
the end of the industrial economy and
the birth of a new economy the consumer
economy in which power shifted from the
heads of manufacturing those who
produced to the heads of sales and
marketing those who created desire and
demand for products and Power in the
marketplace shifted from the worker the
person who produced to the consumer the
person who purchased
and the symbol of that economy was the
credit card that vehicle that allowed
people to buy things even when they
didn't have any money well that economy
ended last fall with black Sunday and
the beginning of the financial collapse
because we discovered we had so inflamed
desires over the last 50 years that now
people wanted more things than they
could possibly ever use or possibly ever
Ford this new economy that's just
emerged has a new Central economic actor
it's not the worker the person who
produces nor the person who consumes the
purchaser it's a new actor that does
both things at the same time call them a
Creator they both create and consume in
the same single act and we're just
beginning to see the shape of this new
economy and it changes not
just the economy itself it's going to
change the whole nature of the work
relationship I'm not sure the notion of
employee or job is going to survive the
transition over the next couple of
decades the very notion of a full-time
job will seem as quaint in 20 years as
the notion of someone getting a gold
watch at their retirement in the 1950s
